The race started at Semerwater lake and would finish at Fleet Moss, which is the highest road in Yorkshire, about 350 meters up. This was easy for the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill first. They quickly shook hands and then started the race. Alistair rode fast on his bike, while Jonny got in the car and drove off. The question was, who would finish first?
Jonny’s confidence dropped quickly. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he saw a big tractor on the road. “Welcome to Yorkshire,” he said to the cameraman. “If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!” After getting past the tractor, Jonny drove on. Meanwhile, Alistair was having a hard time with the hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the slope, while sheep watched him.
Finally, Alistair reached the top of the hill. The sun came out, and he started to ride faster. In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The roads in Yorkshire are old and narrow. He had to drive slowly around a tight corner and through a small stream on the road. After leaving the last village, Jonny drove straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close they were to each other.
As Jonny drove fast to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. He pushed hard and then stopped suddenly at the finish line. “Is he here?” he asked the crowd. “No? Really?” He raised his arms in joy. “Yes!” A few minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car and got out. “Well done,” he said to Alistair, looking disappointed. “I’m sad.” 
**Questions:**
1. Who are the two brothers in the race?
2. What type of vehicle does Jonny use in the race?
3. What does Alistair ride during the race?
4. Where does the race start?
5. What does Jonny say about the weather?
6. What problem does Jonny face while driving?
7. What does Alistair have to do when he reaches the steep hill?
8. How does Alistair feel when he finishes the race?

'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The nice grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all make you feel safe from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. What I find hardest in a tennis match is to focus only on the game and the point I am playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, and people shouting your name. I hear them, but it feels far away. I don’t think about the fifteen thousand people watching me. I am so focused that I don’t realize there are millions watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, told me from a young age that this was the biggest tournament. By the time I was 14, I was dreaming with my friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not so hard. I was just happy to be there at twenty years old. Federer beat me easily. But my loss in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have played better. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, my tough coach, usually does not comfort me, but he told me there was no reason to cry and that there would be more Wimbledons. I told him he didn’t understand, that this might be my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment counts, but some moments are more important, and I had let a big one go in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to help me feel better. But he was right in the end. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my loss. The best sign that I was ready was that I believed I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we did not talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to talk about it, but they understood that I was already thinking about the match in my mind. From then until the match started, that space in my mind was mine alone.'

'A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa in April 1957. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always wanted.” She spent most of her life in Africa as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Jane became famous when Britain’s National Geographical Society published articles and made television shows about her research on chimpanzees. She also wrote popular books, including children’s books and the bestseller In the Shadow of Man, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most famous female scientists of the 20th century. However, her fame sometimes makes people forget her real achievements. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on her adventures and not her important work. Jane Goodall should be recognized for her groundbreaking research on chimpanzees. She helped us understand their social and emotional lives. Before her work, people thought wild chimpanzees were very dangerous, but they misunderstood the risks. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. We also did not know that chimpanzees have emotions similar to humans and that their social lives are like ours. Jane’s book, The Chimpanzees of Gombe (1986), is the most important work on chimpanzee research. Her long study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered a great scientific achievement. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves as humans. Even as a child, Jane showed signs of becoming a biologist. When she was five years old, one autumn day, she disappeared. The police and her family searched for her. After a long search, she came back with straw in her hair and clothes. Her mother asked where she had been. Jane said she wanted to know how hens lay eggs, so she hid in a henhouse for five hours until she got her answer. This moment can be seen as the start of her career as a biologist.'

In our first conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using different voices. She sounds like a funny 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, an old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. Many people know her voices from children’s TV shows and cartoons. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says. “I had to learn how to say many medical words quickly.” 
Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors think they can do funny voices, and some can,” she says. “But it is more than that. You have to make the script exciting for people who cannot see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions, but they often do not get the job because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.”
After school, Shirley took a drama course. She wanted to be an actor. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man at the recording studio asked me to try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I didn’t study drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and got the part!” Shirley discovered she could do voices and thought voiceover work might be good for her. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”
Adult women often do the voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are higher than those of men. There are many rules and forms to follow when hiring child actors, which production companies want to avoid. Shirley has learned to make different sounds and to not always sound the same. She collects new voices by watching children’s TV. 
Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are hard because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my experience helps,” she says. “I learned that smiling while you talk makes your voice sound happy.” When she works on animation, it feels like a holiday because she enjoys working with other actors.
The competition for voiceover work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording that shows what an artist can do – is very important. “It’s worth making a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she is successful because of her hard work and talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel or practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”
For anyone who wants to do voiceovers, Shirley suggests going to special workshops that teach different types of voiceover work. She also thinks it is important to love human sounds. She describes herself as someone who is very interested in voices and becomes the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing an American voice, for example, I might talk like that for hours or even days,” she says. “My children are used to me talking in different voices.”

'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is normal because cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people stop dreaming and choose more practical jobs, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. It seems silly to think you can make a living by drawing simple pictures, but some people do it. 
Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist. I loved comic strips, drew for school papers, and was known as "the kid who draws." I studied graphic design in college and after I graduated, I showed my drawings to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper that wanted political cartoons about local issues. I created some ideas, and they bought them. Soon, I was making enough money to support myself.
You don’t need much to be a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it was that easy, there would be many more cartoonists. The skills needed to be a cartoonist are not hard to learn, but it is still a tough job. You should only try to be a cartoonist if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and gives you time for family and hobbies.
The more skills you have, the better chance you have to make a living with your art. I have done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also written, drawn caricatures, and sometimes designed. I take any job because you can learn a lot from work you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.
What about the business side of being a cartoonist? In the past, many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But now, most cartoonists have to be entrepreneurs. This means you not only create the work, but you also have to sell it. The more comfortable you are with selling, the better you will do. I have seen cartoonists with average drawing skills but great business skills do much better than those who are very talented but don’t know how to sell their work.
Many people worry about someone stealing their ideas, even if they have never sold a cartoon. Some are so scared that they won’t let anyone see their work! To protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will care about your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it can actually be a lucky break!'

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a nice, black guitar from Japan. I usually don’t like to throw things away, so I was surprised that I wanted to get rid of it. I took it to the dump and was about to put it in the trash when a young man came up to me. He looked confused and said, “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” I told him I was, and I started to feel sad. He asked if he could have it, and I said “Yes.” After that, I felt very sad about giving it away.
A few months ago, I opened an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean. Ten years later, he found it in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I read an email from a man named Keith Rushton, who fixes and sells guitars. He told me, “I have your electric guitar.” It had been sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found my name on a label on the guitar and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy! I would have given him anything for it, but his price was fair.
I remembered how my dad liked to put name labels on my things, including my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it; it was calming and gentle. But I didn’t get better at it, so I switched to electric guitar and played easier songs. At that time, punk music was also popular, and anyone could be a rock star, even if they didn’t play well.
When I opened the box that Keith sent me, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave me the guitar. It felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put a strap on my shoulder because electric guitars are played while standing. My fingers remembered where to go. I couldn’t draw the chords, but my hands knew what to do. My fingers felt a little pain from pressing the strings to play a chord. 
Electric guitars are usually played in a band. Now that I am learning again, I think I should form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves “The Regainers”!

There has been a lot of talk about sleep recently. When I wrote the book Insomniac, about people who cannot sleep, I felt like I was the only one warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep can affect our minds, bodies, and feelings. People who have trouble sleeping know how important sleep is. It is good that sleep is getting more attention now. But what about dreams? I have not heard much about dreams in this discussion. We are losing dreams all the time. When you wake up early because of an alarm, you miss the last hour or two of sleep. This lost sleep is mostly REM sleep, which is the stage of sleep when we dream the most. Our best and most memorable dreams happen in REM sleep just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM. So, if a person lives for 90 years, they will spend six or seven years in REM sleep. When researchers take away REM sleep from people, they have more REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This shows that dreams are important. 
In 1953, researchers found REM sleep. Many people agreed with the psychologist Sigmund Freud, who said that understanding dreams was the best way to understand our minds. But later studies showed that it is not that simple. Now, researchers focus more on the physical reasons for dreams rather than the psychological ones. According to Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University, there is not much agreement among dream researchers. 
Dreams are important. At a meeting of sleep experts, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study. This study found that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. Pagel believes that people who are interested in being creative use their dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wonder, do only creative people use their dreams? Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? 
Stickgold says that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways. They help us find new patterns and make connections that we do not usually see. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to think of something related to a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They think of unexpected ideas that make sense in a different way. This is what creativity is. I find that I write better when I wake up from strong dreams. Even a bad dream can help me think better. On those days, my ideas come out quickly, and I can hardly keep up with my typing. I do not know how it works, but it does help. 
Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complicated world. Everyone needs their brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to live in a small town by the sea in south-west England. When you enter her studio, you see many empty frames on the walls and pictures of her two daughters. Susie is a talented copyist artist. She can copy famous paintings from the early 20th century and the 16th century very well. “I don’t keep my own paintings,” Susie says. “As soon as I finish them, I sell them.” 
Susie is very popular. In her 30 years as a copyist, she has painted works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that art experts sometimes think they are the real paintings. While the original paintings can sell for millions of pounds, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how long she works on them. 
Susie does not share the names of her clients, but they include art galleries and private collectors. Some collectors love art, but others want to show off their paintings. One famous buyer likes to say he has a ‘Van Gogh’ painting, but it is really a ‘Susie Ray Van Gogh’. “Many famous people pretend my copies are the originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors keep the original painting in a bank and show Susie’s copy at home.
Susie is honest about her work. When she copies a famous painting, she tries to make it look as real as possible. She believes that doing a bad job would be unfair to the original artist. However, she puts her signature on the back of her paintings. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real painting, and even though some people make money that way, Susie has never wanted to do that. People who make fake art often get into trouble. 
Susie is not rich, and she has had hard times, but now her life is more stable. She does not want to risk her good name with collectors and artists. Susie did not always copy paintings. After finishing her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden. She earned very little money, but it helped her learn important skills. She had to be very careful and get things right the first time. She is happy she found a job that pays better.
When young artists ask Susie for advice, she tells them to learn to draw well and to be accurate. She has studied a lot to do her work. She can draw plants and make copies of old paintings, but she now focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie thinks many people believe modern art is easy. However, she knows that impressionists painted quickly but also paid attention to detail, which is very hard to do.
Some people wonder why Susie does not create her own art. Isn’t art about expressing yourself? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? Susie says her work comes from years of practice, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried to create her own art before. Once, she painted fishing nets, but they looked too much like photographs. 
Susie is a perfectionist, and she wants everything to be just right.

Ellen MacArthur loved the sea more than anything else when she was a racer. She wanted to be the fastest person on the water. Since she was a child, the sea was her big passion. She felt a special connection with her boats. They worked together as one. When she was back on land, life felt boring. People wanted to know about her races, but she just wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that were very dangerous for her.
After she finished second in a big race called the Vendée Globe, she showed me her small boat, Kingfisher. She took me into the tiny cabin where she lived for 94 days. She talked about how she planned everything carefully, even how many rolls of kitchen paper she needed. She said preparation was very important. She proudly showed me her food, a small gas stove, and bags of medical supplies. She took great care of her boat because her life depended on it.
Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small and beautiful, but also fragile. She had a big change in her thinking when she visited South Georgia, a lonely island in the south Atlantic. There, she helped with a study of albatross birds. This experience made her think differently. She saw many old whaling stations and felt it was a warning. She realized that people often take what they want and then leave.
When I visited Ellen at her office, she was finishing a busy phone call. She told me why we need to act now to save the planet. She said that coal, oil, and gas are precious resources that we cannot make again. We need to find ways to use less. At first, she focused on using less, but then she found a better way to think about it. Now, she talks about re-using things, like special carpet tiles that can be used again.
For the last three years, she has been visiting factories and talking to people in government and business about our need for renewable resources. She said, “I will never be an expert, but I love learning new things. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Sailing felt selfish compared to this work. It is important to find out how I can help.”
Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people think about a sustainable future. She said, “I miss the adventure of being at sea. It is part of who I am. When I am sailing, I feel connected to everything. I don’t feel lonely. I focus on my goals and survival. My new message is not as simple as saying, ‘I want to be the fastest around the world.’ I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I have done.”

Jordan Romero is 13 years old. He wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous. He hopes to inspire other kids to go outside and climb their own mountains. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Few people do this before they are thirty years old. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might finish before he turns 20.
Many famous climbers think it is not a good idea to take a 13-year-old up Mount Everest. They believe that while Jordan may be strong, he might not be emotionally ready. They also think he may not have enough experience to make good decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know people criticize us, but we have a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we believe our experience will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature."
I wonder if Jordan wants to climb because of his father's dreams. Paul says, "This is not about me wanting to be famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought about climbing later in life, but we decided, 'Why not now?' We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it." When I ask Jordan why he wants to climb, he says, "I just focus on reaching my goal."
In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest climber. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb is a chance to set a record. This creates a problem for Jordan. Some people think that trying to achieve records takes away the fun of climbing. But if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to share his journey online, take photos, and give interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym."

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, they are probably not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they look confused. I just started a music degree, but my classmates know as little about classical music as other teenagers. If you don’t know who wrote the music, you probably don’t have any of their recordings. This is sad for people who love classical music. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music, and the average classical recording sells only 300 copies. I find this hard to believe.
So, why are fewer people interested in classical music? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that is the reason. The truth is that classical music does not attract most people, especially teenagers, who buy the most music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I don’t really like classical music. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music listening is probably close to that 3% number.
Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, classical music has many changes in mood and rhythm, which can be hard for us. We like fast talking, fast playing, and fast thinking. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Also, pop music talks about things that matter to teenagers, while classical music often does not.
The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would play music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely hear classical music in our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that more people are going to classical concerts now. Maybe, but I don’t think many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why more middle-aged people like classical concerts, but if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it.
Some people say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids want to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay after school to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they play it, but it is not their favorite music. Playing and listening to music have become different activities. When we want to relax, we always choose pop music. 
**Questions:**
1. What type of music do most teenagers listen to?
2. How many concert tickets sold last year were for classical music?
3. Why do teenagers find classical music hard to enjoy?
4. What do teenagers prefer to listen to when they want to relax?
5. Do many teenagers go to classical music concerts?

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I will make you sorry I came here,” she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the other door, so she didn’t hear Bonnie, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hill; it was confusing at first. Then she saw signs: Science block, gym, riding center… “Riding center,” said Bonnie, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” said her mother. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. “I wish you would walk beside me instead of behind me like a dog,” said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do it. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she said to herself. “I will be thrown out soon anyway,” she said to the door, “so why not just go?” She left the building and went to the riding center, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a big place for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one there. She walked carefully to the horses. Bonnie treated horses with respect. The horses were well cared for, and she could see that. Almost every stall had a horse, and she looked at each one. “I know what you are doing here,” she said to a small pony, touching its nose. Then she saw the next horse and stopped. “But aren’t you the best!” she said. He was brown with a little white. He looked lively, and Bonnie liked that. “I feel like we have met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “It was in my dreams, and I was riding you to win a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride the horse. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle,” she thought. The room with the riding equipment was unlocked. Happy to put a saddle on Maverick, she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You are the best horse I have ever ridden, Maverick,” she said. “I know about horses, even if I don’t know about anything else.” She nudged him to walk, then to trot. “If I stay here, I think we could be great friends,” she said. She went around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, and a little breeze made her cheek feel warm. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

'I have met Cody Simpson before, and I was impressed by his quiet confidence. Cody is a 15-year-old boy from Australia. He has already released many successful songs. How did a relaxed surfer end up on stage in front of many fans? Cody says, “I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven.” He remembers that he was swimming and surfing every day. These activities were very important to him. When he was 13, he was in high school and posted some videos online. 
These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans wanted to see more videos on social media. So, Cody recorded more videos at home, and the responses were amazing. Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with great coaches and focused on swimming. But then, record labels contacted him, and he had to make a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming or take a big risk by moving to the US with his family. Cody decided to take the risk. 
He said, “It was very difficult for me to choose a career at such a young age. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 years old and trying to figure out what you want to do for the rest of your life?” He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. “It surprised most people. I’m the quiet kid,” he remembers. “I’m modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world.” 
So, Cody packed his bags and moved with his family to another part of the world, giving up one dream to try to make another dream come true. His family stays out of the spotlight and does not work directly in his career, but they support him. Cody believes it is important to have good people around you to stay grounded. 
Everyone has days of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight years old, and he travels the world and does school on the road. He doesn’t have a regular life,” Cody admits. “I worry about him sometimes, but my family always supports me in everything I do.” 
Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big chance, even when it is scary. “It all happened so fast and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I go to countries I never thought I would visit and play in front of many fans. It is something many people dream of. But I know it won’t last forever.”'

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. A new crack in the ice shone in the morning sun. I squinted and looked upstream at the sandbags. They were there to stop the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags. Last week, I worked with many people in the town for long hours to help. My grandfather did not notice much. 
With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the dark water from the factory in Milltown. There was thin ice on both sides, and the dark water was followed by solid ice. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I did not know him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and put on my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather gave me from a trip to South America. This chain is special, and only my grandfather, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that trip. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen. 
“Good morning, Rex,” my mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I will make brunch after your training. Be careful.” 
“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his room. 
“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 
“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was clear because I was wearing my wetsuit. Grandpa is sometimes hard to deal with, and he has been more difficult lately. 
“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came over with a kind smile. 
“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 
“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I wanted to say he was always like this, but I kept quiet. When I was a child, he was my hero. He showed me pictures of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old pictures still hang on his wall, above his medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own picture in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay close to him, even if he is grumpy. 
Mom smiled. “At least he is coming out of his room more. Have a good training session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even on these cold days!” 
I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It will be warmer in South America,” I said. “If I find sponsors for my trip.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. “Come with me,” she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was a painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s, but it looked different and was not finished. “Do you know anything about this?” Mum asked. Jess shook her head. “I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything.” 
Jess looked at the painting. There was a river in it, but it was not a river she knew. It looked like a fantasy river. The painting was strange and beautiful in a spooky way. The riverbank was very small, with a little green that was hard to see. The eye was drawn to the pale water and a hidden sea. There were no animals, no birds, and no people. It felt right that way. Jess thought about autumn coming after a long summer. 
Mum spoke again. “It has a name.” There was something in her voice that showed her excitement. Jess knew why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others think about them. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. “River Boy.” The words felt important to her, but she didn’t know why. 
Then Jess noticed something. She looked at Mum. “There is no boy.” 
“Exactly. It’s strange, isn’t it? For him to be so specific. But maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it.” 
“Mum! You should have known better.” 
“I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess what he said.” 
Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would say. “He told you it’s not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, just like a poem. We either understand it or we don’t. And he said painting is hard work without having to explain it to everyone.” 
Mum laughed. “Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him.” 
“Inspire?” 
“Someone who helps an artist.” Jess knew what it meant. Grandpa often said it when she watched him paint, but he never said it was about her. She thought he meant a goddess, not a real person. It was hard to think anyone could inspire someone as stubborn as Grandpa. “He doesn’t need me to inspire him,” she said. “He’s been painting all his life.”

This morning, I woke up and did not mean to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I am not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s knife in my hand, the knife might have gone into the carpet and made a big hole. I did not mean to damage the carpet. I did not wake up and think, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me a lot. 
What I was really doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It is very cute! It is small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran kept china ornaments in there. I keep my shells and stones there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was very happy when she gave it to me! 
The cabinet is a corner cabinet, so it is shaped like a triangle. It has to stand in a corner. My bedroom is the smallest room in the house, and it is shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad’s; the back one is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and my room is very small. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I will be in my small room for a long time. 
I do not mind; I like my little bedroom. It is cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is, there are not many corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. Then I thought, if I cannot cut the cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like a good solution. Dad always tells us to “think outside the box.” That is what I was trying to do!

'The novel "The Borrowers" is about a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They "borrow" things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV show based on the book, I knew it would be hard to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should be. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn’t want people to say I did it wrong. The author wanted the show to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans' view, which made filming more difficult. 
The most important thing was to get the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans. So, when we filmed the Borrowers walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be ten times further away than usual. When filming the human world around the Borrowers, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for some special shots. 
One big challenge was to make the shadows look right when we combined the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We created a special way to do this. After the show was on TV, famous director George Lucas called me to ask how I did it. The only set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floor, filled with big objects to make the actors look small. It was very strange. When I asked them to carry big things like giant scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins – they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because the crew laughed so much. 
In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary that they didn’t have to act. It was important to me to get the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they looked like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the main actress to move. She couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor wore trousers made from a rug because normal fabric would look too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they were happy with me for the costumes!
Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen. It was hard for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how they should look – I drew 2,000 by the end. They weren’t perfect, but they worked. We didn’t have enough money to use special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once filmed a whole scene and then realized there was no film in the camera! But in the end, everything came together, and I think the show was successful in showing the magic of the books.'

"Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, searching for reporters that are not there. I know the craziness will start soon. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones who ask for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. ‘Everything will be fine,’ I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone at this new school. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I wanted to come to this school because I want to meet normal kids. Kids with parents who have regular jobs, like working in an office or cutting grass. That would be so cool. 
I walk into the school office. ‘Hi, I need my schedule, please,’ I say to the secretary. ‘Name?’ she asks, looking unfriendly. ‘Desert McGraw.’ ‘Desirée?’ she asks, leaning closer. ‘Desert,’ I say again. The secretary looks confused. ‘Oh,’ she says and types ‘McGraw’ on her computer. That’s good because not many people know my last name since my dad uses a stage name. ‘What grade?’ she asks. ‘Eleventh.’ ‘One moment, it’s printing,’ she says. Then she rips the paper and gives it to me. English Literature, first period. Great, I like English. But I will be late. English is in Room 214, on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look silly searching for my classes. 
When I reach the door, I hear the teacher calling names. ‘Aurelio Gonzalez.’ ‘Here.’ I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. She looks at my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. ‘Nice shoes,’ she whispers. I look down at my fancy shoes with flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. ‘Thanks,’ I say. The teacher pauses. ‘Desert... McGraw?’ she says carefully. ‘Here.’ The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we look at them, she lets us talk! All teachers should do this. 
‘So why did you move here?’ my new friend asks. I have many answers. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason my dad gave? ‘We need a change, Desert,’ he said, ‘and this is the best place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.’ I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a studio close to the sand? ‘My dad had to move,’ I tell her. Yes, lies are easier. ‘What does he do?’ she asks. Oh well. Everyone will find out soon. But I can pretend to be normal for a while. ‘He’s an artist,’ I say, playing with my backpack zipper. ‘Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.’ And she doesn’t seem to care. Great."

Today, many American teenage girls are expected to be the president of the Student Council. They also need to have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in school. This is what it means to be a teenager in America now. Boys and girls cannot just go to school and be average; they need to do more. If they do not try hard, people think they are lazy.
Kristen Loose, a teenager, says, “Adults often forget how much pressure we have. We have a lot of homework, tests, after-school activities, jobs, chores, and we also want to have a social life.” Even with all this stress, people still have negative ideas about teenagers. They think teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, loud, and only care about themselves. While some teenagers may act this way, Kristen believes it is not fair to say all teenagers are like this.
Kristen uses her cellphone a lot, but not just for fun. She uses it to help with her schoolwork and to stay in touch with people. Today, students can do their homework anywhere because of smartphones and tablets. They can listen to lessons while going to school. Schoolwork does not stop when they leave school; it takes a lot of their time.
Many teenagers wake up around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often go to bed after midnight. They have school, activities, family duties, and homework. They usually do not get enough sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teenagers get the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. Also, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school once a week because they are tired.
Lindamarie Olsen, another teenager, says she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. She does not spend her free time on social media or watching TV. Instead, she likes to volunteer. Lindamarie says, “People think teenagers only care about themselves, but I love helping others. I want to make a positive difference in my school and community.”
In the future, the ideas about teenagers may change, but they will continue to show that these ideas are wrong and make the world a better place. There will always be new students who are doing great things before they finish school.
---
**Questions:**
1. What are some of the expectations for American teenage girls today?
2. How does Kristen Loose feel about the pressure on teenagers?
3. What does Kristen use her cellphone for?
4. How many hours of sleep do most teenagers get according to the US National Sleep Foundation?
5. What does Lindamarie Olsen like to do in her free time?

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a small mountain town in the US. This town is surrounded by wild nature, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In the last few years, this group has sent over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long science project that is also an adventure, which is why many teenagers join. 
I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to try to see shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and makes a bright light. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the lunch box, there was a camera, a tool to measure height, and a thermometer to check the temperature as the balloon went up. They also put two GPS trackers on the outside of the lunch box to find it later. 
A gas tank, given by a friend from another state, was used to fill the balloon with gas. The balloon slowly grew to the size of a small car. An older boy drove for seven hours to get the gas tank. “I didn’t really mind,” he said. For kids in this club, this is normal. 
Finally, it was time for the balloon to go up. “Five, four, three, two, one,” they counted down, and the balloon started to rise. Some of them ran and followed it with bright flashlights until they could not see it anymore. There was a quiet feeling of wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night sky. 
After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at the clear sky. It was hard to believe they were only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with about 4 million people. I saw a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” said one girl quietly. “I know,” whispered another. 
A meteor shot across the sky. As the balloon rose, the air pressure changed, and the balloon got bigger until it popped with a loud sound. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. 
Finding the lunch box was not easy, but that was part of the fun. There is not much land with people around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. “Recovering the lunch box is a big part of the project,” said the group’s leader. They had lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “This journey helps us know the land better,” he said. 
This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the mountains. They had to decide if they should drive or walk. It could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high mountain or in a tall tree. “These students know the Eastern Sierra well,” their leader said. “What seems wild to some is normal for others.” 
In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera did not catch any shooting stars. This was a little disappointing, but it gave them a chance to talk about science and share another adventure story.

Chloe Morgan says that she did not like science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen years old. It happened by chance. “My younger brother loved dinosaurs, but I did not care about them. I helped him with a science project, and I found an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology. It amazed me! I knew I wanted to study this.” 
I ask her how she got support because Palaeontology was not a common job for young people. “I remember meeting my first palaeontologist,” she laughs. “His name was Matt Cornelius. He was famous, even though he was young. I was very nervous, but he was friendly and listened to me. I felt better when he was patient with my questions.” 
I ask Chloe about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. She thinks for a moment. “Movies like Jurassic Park have made many people interested in dinosaurs, but not in Palaeontology itself. I welcome this interest, but I think movies often show palaeontologists in a wrong way. We are either seen as strange geniuses or as silly people who cannot talk to others. Movies do not show what our real jobs are like.” 
I ask her to explain her job. “My job is very different every day. I dig up dinosaur bones, but I also work in labs, studying fossils and writing for science magazines. Sometimes, I talk to the public about science. I think it is important to help people understand science better. I want to reach young people because it is good for them to learn about science. Talking about dinosaurs can get children excited about nature and help them learn more.” 
The recent TV show Walking with Dinosaurs was a good chance for Chloe to help show dinosaurs on screen. She says the people who made the show knew what they were doing, and she was there to give advice. “I did not have to say much because the dinosaurs looked good. I mostly checked that the dinosaurs lived at the same time. We attracted many viewers because we have learned a lot about dinosaurs, and the ones in this show are very different from those in movies like Jurassic Park. They look more real than ever.” 
I ask Chloe why she thinks dinosaurs still interest us. “I think they make us curious. We want to discover new things. Even when our world feels small, dinosaurs remind us that there is still much to learn. Palaeontology is like time travel.”

I will say this once: when you are traveling by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know that you are not ‘there yet,’ even when you keep asking, ‘Are we there yet?’ The truth is, when you arrive, it is not ‘there’ anymore; it is ‘here.’ So if you think you are ‘there’ yet, you should ask, ‘Are we here yet?’ 
I am sure that no one wants to be ‘there yet’ more than the parents who hear this question over and over on long car trips. What are kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn’t you like to relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while looking at the beautiful views outside the window. 
In the front seat, there is mum or dad, helping with juice boxes, cookies, and changing the radio. They keep everything running smoothly. 
But then, someone in the car does something annoying – usually my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let him do that, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, we are fighting, and our parents have to separate us while driving. They tell Tim to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This helps for a while, and we can enjoy the views again. 
Later, I try to read, but I feel a draft on my arm. The window is closed, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, breathing on me. He is not touching me, so he thinks it is okay. This makes me angry. Tim gets yelled at again, and the car swerves. 
Over the years, Dad has found ways to deal with us in the back seat. When we ask, ‘Are we there yet?’ he often says, ‘Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.’ But we are still on the highway, going fast. Then he says, ‘Oh, maybe we’re not there yet.’ This keeps us quiet for a bit. 
You can tell when you are finally ‘there’ when the adults get out of the car and move far away from the kids. So remember: if mum and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no. You are not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK. In their café, people can enjoy coffee and cake while playing board games. The owners hope that customers will love the experience and come back again. Zuzi says they wanted to create a place where people can be together and talk, not just look at their phones and screens.
The games played in John and Zuzi's café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games have simple themes, like farming and building. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, made by a German designer named Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources with each other. Everyone stays involved and no one feels left out. 
Later, cooperative games were made, where all players work together to win or lose as a team. One popular cooperative game is Pandemic, created by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on a book. He remembers feeling scared and excited when he played it with friends. He wanted to create a game that made people feel good, whether they won or lost.
Leacock loved board games as a child, but he often felt disappointed when they did not meet his expectations. With help from his uncle, he tried to make better games using pieces from other games. Pandemic became very successful and had a lot of storytelling. It is like a video game because players develop characters and the story changes as they play.
The video game industry has helped board games become popular. Many people now play games on their phones. Ben Hogg, who works for a game company, says that everyone plays games on their smartphones. More people are open to playing games than ever before.
At first, video games allowed people to play together in person, like at arcades or on the sofa. But then, many video games moved online, and players could not see each other. Some people who liked video games wanted to play games with others in person again. 
In John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, games are now something to share with others in real life, and this trend will continue. 
**Questions:**
1. Where is John and Zuzi's café located?
2. What do people enjoy at the café besides coffee and cake?
3. What are Eurogames known for?
4. Who created The Settlers of Catan?
5. What is the main idea of the game Pandemic?
6. How did Matt Leacock feel about board games when he was a child?
7. Why have board games become more popular today?

Jamie Scott has written and produced many popular songs in the UK. His story shows that hard work and not giving up are very important in the music business, even if you start with many failures. He says his mother was a great singer and helped him learn to play the guitar. The only radio he listened to at home was a local station for older people. This explains why he did not hear modern songs until he was 12 years old. At that time, he had to choose between playing tennis and making music. He played tennis at a high level, but he preferred music. He spent his lunch breaks in the music room at school, learning songs on the piano.
At 17, he left school to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but did not want to perform. Jamie told his parents that he wanted to make music. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed; if he did not, he would need to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he got signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, the record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to leave his friend.
Jamie found success as a songwriter instead of a performer. After a tough time with a record label in the UK, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. He did not become famous right away. He felt he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time as an artist, but as a writer, he was in the right place. He believes he is one of the main writers that UK labels turn to for new artists. He helps them understand that wanting to write popular songs is okay.
Jamie wants to write big songs that people love. He is not arrogant; he knows he has a talent for writing number one songs. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on making great music. He says, “When I go into the studio, we need to write the best music for next year. It’s not just about what is cool. We want to write classic pop songs.” 
**Questions:**
1. What did Jamie Scott's mother help him learn?
2. At what age did Jamie first hear a modern song?
3. What sport did Jamie play at a high level?
4. How long did Jamie's dad give him to succeed in music?
5. What does Jamie want to write when he goes into the studio?

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is a big star online, but many people, like me, do not know him because we do not watch online videos of people doing tricks on bikes. He is a "street trials cyclist." This means he jumps from hard places, like roofs or walls, to land safely in other strange places. People film these jumps and post them online.
I met Tony in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local boys know who he is, and some older people come to tell him he is "an absolute legend." After watching him, I agree. At first, I was not sure about him, but I was surprised by his courage and creativity. Before each jump, he explains what he wants to do, and sometimes I cannot believe he will succeed. When I compliment him, he seems not very happy. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he does not like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to talk to fans. He prefers to do things instead of just talking about them.
Tony knows that social media and cameras help him make money. He says, "Sometimes I feel everyone is holding a camera or looking at a screen, and I do not like that." But he is not complaining. He makes a good living from his videos, which used to be just a hobby for people like him.
After many years of talking to top athletes, I think two things help a child become a great competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are often more important than talent. The riskier the sport, the more mental strength you need. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what he thought were easy obstacles. He just got up and kept trying until he succeeded.
Some people do not see Tony as a hero. They think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He says, "People who say this may care, but they do not understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and do not know the sport. They do not see that I get advice from experts to stay safe." 
Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, "People are different. Some are not scared, and they should not do these sports. It is smart to know the dangers. Some people cannot get over their fear, but I can. I feel fear but find a way to move past it. I am not addicted to risk. I spend a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes I ride around to get ready before trying a new jump. I know I must stay calm before I jump. If I focus completely, then I am fine."
**Questions:**
1. What type of cyclist is Tony Connor?
2. Where did the interview with Tony take place?
3. How do local boys feel about Tony?
4. What does Tony think about being a celebrity?
5. What two qualities help a child become a great competitor, according to the writer?
6. How does Tony feel about the risks he takes?

'Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire. This wire was 66 metres above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net. She wore a belt around her waist that was attached to another wire above her. To help her keep her balance, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. 
Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. She already had some circus skills, but she found out that high-wire walking was very different. ‘The training was a shock,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill. Then I did an hour of exercises, and another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But I had to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’
On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen controlled herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-metre walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said afterwards. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ But this experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

'In 2006, Jeff Somers started a trip around the world on a penny farthing, an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. He had already written a book about his travels in Canada in a 50-year-old car. He loved motor sports and worked building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and used it to go to Amsterdam for a holiday. “That trip opened my eyes,” he says. “I decided to see the world by bike.” Jeff did not want a normal touring bike and wanted to build one himself. “The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to learn how they were made.” After two tries in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally started his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. “Even though I met cyclists who could ride up mountains, which I could not do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further I went from home, the more amazed people were by it.” His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got a serious fever and stayed in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days. He had no money for a hospital or to go home. But despite all this, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”'

"I work at a university in the US. My team and I are learning about water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a special tool called a ‘night-vision scope’. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are worried about black ducks because their numbers have gone down a lot. We do not know if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about what they do during the day, but we do not know what they do at night because we did not have the right equipment. The new scope will give us clear pictures, even when there is no moon. This will help us learn more and make better choices to protect their home. 
It is hard work. There are four of us, and we each work six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places. I have taken a boat to some areas and written down notes about every duck I see. The weather has not been good. Some nights are warm, but most nights are wet. It is very quiet, and I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. I like this challenge, especially when I think about summer. In summer, we will work in a laboratory and look at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this work. I would not change it for anything!"

"When I tell people what my job is, they often don’t believe me. But I’m serious! I spend my days at work eating chocolate! Tasting chocolate is very important to make sure that customers get good chocolate from my company. Every week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate, from our factory. I check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit. I spend time choosing the best ones to put in the chocolate. 
Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make. I also share samples with my colleagues! My kitchen has many machines and ingredients to use. It’s great to have a private space during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I am in our food lab, and other times I travel to buy our raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family. But I love the variety in my job, even more than the chocolate!
People often ask me if I get bored of chocolate. I have worked with it for a long time, and I never feel tired of eating it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!"

'Have you ever thought about what it is like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching balls, and trapeze, which is flying in the air above an amazed audience. 
In the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see how their children are doing. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to do different things all the time. It is important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part of this job is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important. Circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have creativity, and always want to improve their skills. 
People often think you will get hurt or that you can only work for a short time each year. But the real issue is thinking about the future because you can only travel while you are young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many former students start their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their stories. Sophia warns, however, that it is not a job for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not have a regular salary. It is also competitive, but it is a lot of fun!”'

'You may not know her name or her face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a backing singer. A backing singer helps the main singer by singing in the background. Many people think that backing singers are not good enough to be main singers. This is not true – they often have to be better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music world! 
“What I love about my job is that when I go into the recording studio, I never know what I will sing,” she says. “It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. It might also be a funny song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what the producers ask me to do. One time, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do my job!”
“Excellent musical skills are very important for my work, and I need to learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. I will never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, and there was an orchestra too. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, and nobody likes that. Recording sessions are long enough already.”
“One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers do not always know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can see how to make it better.”'

'Julie Deane started with only basic knowledge of fashion, but she created a successful business with her ‘satchels’ - a traditional bag used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before she chose to make satchels, Julie thought about different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She wanted to make the best choice. When she decided to make satchels, not everyone agreed with her. Julie said, “Many people said there was no need for them – but I believed in my idea.” She worked with her family from the beginning, especially her mother, who had never worked before but was good at business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. 
Julie did not know much about fashion blogs, but they helped her succeed. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To get more interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers and hoped they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and more people became interested. Now, her company makes satchels faster. Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity is seen with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online ads, she uses the internet to get ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. 
There was a hard time when another company copied Julie’s design to sell similar bags. Because of this, she now makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors say there is a positive feeling in her offices – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place.'

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky liked to do many sports. She was a good swimmer, and her swimming coach thought she could be a champion. But the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to train and do her schoolwork.
When they were teenagers, Jamie loved cycling. He bought a special racing bike and started to compete. Vicky thought cycling looked exciting and decided to try it too. She says it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was near her school, so it was easy for her to go to training after school.
Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won many competitions. When she was 28, she stopped competing. Vicky said, “I loved winning for many years, but I started to feel tired of it. When the excitement goes away, there is no point in continuing. Luckily, I found a new job.”
Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. “We work with young people who have never liked sports,” she says. “The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job and helps young people feel part of a group.”
The charity uses famous people to promote their work. Vicky says, “Some people think having a celebrity help a charity is not always good. They say celebrities do it for their own benefit, which can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.”

'Ana Ronson is a singer-songwriter from Ireland. Her parents did not play music, but there was always music in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was very nervous, and her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested that Ana join the school theatre club to help her feel more confident. After some time in the club, she sang happily with 50 other students at a concert.
A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. Ana wrote her first song, called Falling Stars, in just three days. She enjoyed it so much that she took a songwriting course with a professional. Even though she was the youngest student, she knew a lot about music. But Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about how this made her feel. She shared this song online, and many people loved it and found new meanings in the words.
Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, flew from the other side of Ireland to ask Ana to join his company. At first, Ana was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. But Joss convinced her that this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. All the tickets sold quickly, and it was a wonderful evening.
Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times in life, as she feels she has more to say then. One of her favorite songs is Decision, which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how sad it made him. Ana hopes her fans will like her songs, but she wants to write about her own important experiences.'

'Last year, I went on a great trip. I traveled by boat on a guided tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write stories about the trip. He loves boats, but I do not share that interest. I had always wanted to visit this area because I saw it on TV when I was a child. I knew it was where our great-grandparents lived before they moved to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could go with him, and he finally said yes!
A few days before we left, there were storms where we were going. But the weather forecast said it would be calm when we arrived. I was busy at work and did not have much time to prepare, but Harry said he would take care of everything, so I stopped worrying.
When we arrived in Canada, we joined the group, packed our things into small boats, and started our journey. The guide told us that very few people live along that coast. On the first morning, the only animals we saw were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the morning fog made it hard to see far. I enjoyed watching the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.
We often stopped to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I did not know. It was nice to forget about time. We always remembered to have lunch and dinner, which we cooked together over campfires. At night, we slept on the boats. The beds were hard, but it felt relaxing!
When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!'

"My dad was a basketball player in Germany, just like his dad before him. When I was a kid, I went to watch many of his games. You might think that watching so many games would make me love basketball, but it did not. I liked telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often took a book to read instead of watching the games.
When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. My sports teacher saw my height and asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training, but I thought I needed to get better before playing in a real game. The teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed to play, and a few weeks later, I played against another school. My parents came to watch, which made me more nervous, but it was OK in the end!
For the next four years, I practiced every day and did very well. I even joined an adult team before I moved to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was great to work with him. However, I did not enjoy living far from my parents at first.
