Pen feels that being part of a team is stressful for him. He is also thinking about his age. “I will be 47 on Thursday. I have not trained as much as I should.” He feels that organizing things always seems more important. He is worried about what he will have to do. Pen believes that this mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge. He says, “Reaching the North Pole was a personal goal, but this time scientists will use the data we collect. We want to involve many people in what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and we are the only ones who can do it.” He adds, “Our skills, which seem strange, are now very useful.”

'I took a year off. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is amazing. I had the chance to do more writing and TV work, and to speak to businesses and schools. Even though I enjoyed these activities, I wanted to compete again. I wanted to stay in shape so I could try for the Olympics if I felt that way again. So, I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about Ben Fogle’s invitation: “Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?” I have always loved rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I missed that feeling, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some competition. I asked my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they were not very excited. I knew that if I entered the race, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? No. But being an underdog with no pressure was interesting. I contacted Ben. He was going to join the race anyway and had found the money for the entry fee and a boat. This made the race feel real, not just a talk. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000 – a lot of money. We thought we had a good chance, but we still needed to work hard to get it. I also had to think about losing money because I would be away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money after being a professional athlete. It is nice that people are interested. But I find it hard to talk about my past without a new goal. Joining the race would mean I wouldn’t just talk about what I did before. I would be doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one big lesson was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. My training for the Olympics was hard, but it was simple. I trained almost every day, but my training plan was clear, and I had doctors and dieticians to help me. I was worried about what people would think of me racing with a TV presenter. I thought it might look like I just wanted to be on TV. My worries went away as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing. It is also about the mind. Ben had done tough challenges, but he could not row well. I was surprised by how little he knew about rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of understanding. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest with Ben about how much he needed to improve. I should have known that would be his level when I agreed to race with him.'

A little over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. I was 26 years old and felt restless. I dreamed of cold, snowy landscapes because I wanted to escape the busy life in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They hired me as a husky dog handler for the winter season. From December to February, they take tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow. They started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. They also took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm,' which is pretty but basic, with bad electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months, but the work would be hard. I started packing right away.
**November 6, London**  
On my flight, I stared at a page with pictures of more than 100 huskies. I was supposed to remember their names, but I felt nervous. I looked out the window instead. I thought about how spring moves north, but I saw winter moving south, with rivers freezing.
**November 7, Helsinki and Hetta**  
The bus ride north was what I hoped for. We drove through dark forests with snow on the trees, stopping for reindeer. I arrived at the farm after dark. As soon as I got in, Anna handed me a pair of boots and sent me outside into the cold. She asked if I wanted to start working right away. I followed the sound of barking and found the dogs. Three people were running around, getting the huskies ready for sleds. The dogs were very excited and wanted to go. I tried to introduce myself, but everyone was too busy. I petted one of the quieter dogs. Someone told me to get in the sled, and I almost fell in. Then we took off into the dark with only a headlamp for light.
**November 15, Hetta**  
I quickly learned how to be a husky guide, but first, Anna asked me if I was useful. I didn’t know how to answer. I realized I wasn’t very useful because I had never driven a snowmobile or used an axe. But when someone asked if I had a driving license, I nodded, feeling relieved. I learned the basics of dog-sledding quickly: lean into the corners, use both feet on the brake to stop, and hold on to the handlebar. But other tasks were hard. Feeding and watering the dogs was difficult in the cold. Water would freeze quickly, so we made a 'soup' of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, I was tired from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled by excited huskies. But I felt proud. I emailed my friends, saying, "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a saw. In the snow."

'On that day, when Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters came to talk about her amazing race. They noted that her time was good enough to let her compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a special treatment called emu oil. This was a product that Olympic gold medal winner, Cathy Freeman, had suggested to help Radcliffe heal after she had an accident while training. Radcliffe says that she did not fully understand how big her achievement was at that moment. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal. But for her, it was just what she was meant to do that day, so it felt normal. She and her team decided not to set limits on what they could achieve. Their motto was: no limits. 
During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried that she might not be able to keep up her fast pace. He thought it might make her drop out of the race. Hartmann was angry about this, but he understood that people who did not know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so fast. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to think about her time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had already run 41 kilometers very quickly, but she still managed to sprint the last distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, ‘I can run faster than that.’ She remembers the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never thought anyone would come close to that time for a long time. Radcliffe thought, “I will come back and do it next year.” Sadly, that did not happen.
After the race, everyone wanted to know how Radcliffe, who ran in a strange way, had beaten the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with Radcliffe for weeks, helping her with her training. He said, ‘I have worked with 63 Olympic medalists, and no one could take the level of pain that she could. She would make me work hard because I had to go deep into her muscles.’ Hartmann talked about traveling 13 hours from his home in Ireland to Radcliffe's training place in France. When he arrived, her husband shouted, ‘Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting.’ There was no time for greetings or tea. Radcliffe was ready for a two-hour training session. She always pushed him to give his best. 
During this time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that other athletes he worked with became upset. Can Radcliffe explain why no one has come close to her record? ‘Not really. I trained very hard, but there are people who are more talented. I thought Mary Keitany (two-time London marathon winner) would do it. Maybe it is because people are racing against each other instead of racing against themselves.’ What does she mean? ‘It is about always pushing yourself, even when you are winning. That probably helped me because I never thought, “I can relax now.” It was always: “keep going as fast as you can.” Radcliffe did not know it then, but that marathon was the best she would ever run. She would not run that fast again. However, she inspired many women to start long-distance running.'

'When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, came out, I did not know how people would like it. There was a lot of talk about a food ‘revolution’ in Britain, and I thought we made a special series that added something new. But I was still worried: would people like a way of cooking that included not just techniques but also history and science? I watched the first show feeling both happy and scared. I did not need to worry. The show became very successful and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my restaurant. In each project, I felt like I was on a journey, whether into the past or into cooking techniques. I wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each one with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often about traveling, with passports and suitcases. In Search of Total Perfection is the latest book, and in it, you will travel around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who makes golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These people have spent many years trying to reach their own idea of perfection. Perfection is different for everyone. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was hard, and I knew I would upset some people by leaving out their favorites. I could imagine people asking, ‘Where is steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?’ But after a long meeting, the TV team and I finally made a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that each person has their own idea of perfection, based on their feelings and memories. Even though the book is called ‘Perfection’, I knew I would not say the recipes were the best. I believed that by using my skills and talking to food producers, chefs, and customers, I could find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says ‘perfection’ means being perfect, but it also means improving through practice. Trying new ideas and changing them until you have something special. The TV show let me explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen before, and I was excited to think about memories in food because I started in this business in the same way. Finding the best ingredients took me all over the world. I had many adventures, like visiting a canning factory that was using the wrong tomatoes and going to a dairy farm that was not good enough for filming! To improve each recipe, I even hand-milked a cow and used dry ice to make ice cream, cooked chicken in a hospital machine, and almost burned my house trying to make a real Neapolitan-style pizza.'

We were still far from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, went off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the front of the van. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets. He looked like he knew what he was doing. “Actually, I don’t know what I’m doing,” he said after a while, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried. “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field was big and had only grass and many flowers, like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I said, because it was better to agree with Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So I told them about how the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I told them what the birds talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But I didn’t sound sure. “Liar,” Bea said. I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? I thought about it and felt confused. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café. It was not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “It’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said when it started to get dark. Mum took out blankets and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on the ground. “I will have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said. Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept thinking about how we would get home now that our van had to be pulled everywhere. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city named Liesel or Louisa. They were both older than Lucy by about ten years. They spoke good English and talked about the music they were playing and their travels. 
“I think I'm going to Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy said. It sounded impressive, but she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She didn’t want to do many things that took up her time, like concerts and competitions. These events made her miss a lot of school, so she wasn’t officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 
Lucy didn’t even want to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. She was lucky to be chosen from thousands of applicants. At the party, her dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to celebrate. Her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took Lucy out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The funny thing was, Lucy hadn’t applied to the festival. Her mom filled out the form and sent in a CD. “I didn’t want you to be sad if you didn’t get in,” her mom said. Lucy thought her mom didn’t want to give her a chance to say no. 
The guy from Tokyo leaned forward. “Tanglewood?” he asked. “Yeah,” Lucy replied. “How old are you?” he asked. “Fifteen,” she said. He looked at Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy didn’t mean to show off. It was hard to know when to share her achievements and when to be quiet. 
“It’s just part of this new youth program they are trying,” she explained. Liesel/Louisa then looked across the room and said she had to go talk to someone. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, messy hair, like many musicians, to show he was a cool music nerd. “Once, when I was about eight,” Lucy answered. 
Just then, Lucy's grandfather came over. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone,” he said, pulling her away from the conversation. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” “They’re not the competition,” Lucy replied. “Everyone is the competition,” her grandfather said. He took her around the room to meet important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of what they said. 
In the elevator to their room after the party, her grandfather said, “You did well, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” Lucy liked that. She liked being someone important, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young. Being a concert pianist didn’t make her special at school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know or care that she could play difficult music. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered. 
---
**Questions:**
1. Where was Lucy at the beginning of the story?
2. Who were the two other pianists Lucy talked to?
3. How old is Lucy?
4. What did Lucy’s dad give her to celebrate?
5. Who filled out the application for the festival?

“It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world,” said Dad. It is hard to argue with him, so I wanted to learn what experts say about this. I found it interesting. 
Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have real-life friends, a good sense of who they are, and learn important skills for the digital world. Simon Miles, an expert on online safety, says that social networking is a big part of growing up today. Teenagers use social media differently than adults. They do not just check emails or buy things; they live in it. This is not good or bad – it depends on how you use it.
How is our social networking different from what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media expert, says it is like hanging out at a youth club. Parents used to do this to share jokes and gossip. Social media helps teenagers find their identity away from their parents and deal with teenage issues with their friends.
Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says that adolescence is a time to ask, “Who am I?” Social networking can help with this. You can share your favorite music or sports, find what you like, and see how others think differently. Research shows that teenagers who use social media are not more self-centered than those who do not. He also says that for shy people, talking online can be easier than in person. It can help them practice social skills in a safe way.
Professor Andrew Phillips studies how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can help quiet people with special interests connect with others. If you are one of the few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a group online with similar interests, you can feel more popular in a different way.
Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared something interesting: “Young people can find new interests online, join groups, and create their own content. This is how they use social networks well.” She thinks social networking is a way to be creative. Teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what they like. Photo-sharing sites help photographers connect, learn, and share their work. 
“This helps with getting jobs in the future,” she says. “Every business uses social media to sell and promote themselves. You need to know how it works to attract customers. For example, if you create a product and have 1000 friends on social networks, they can all be potential customers. If you connect all those networks, you have your customer base.”
Teenagers who use social media creatively will benefit when they become adults and look for jobs, says Matthews. “One great thing about many sites is the chance to work with others to create and share content. Working together is an important skill for jobs in the digital age.”

When most people think of a fun family vacation, they might not think of a long trip through nine western states in the US and one Canadian province. But my parents wanted to have a special summer vacation this year. My dad decided to plan a family trip that my twin brother and I were not excited about. They often said, “Not enough people do this anymore,” while we exchanged worried looks.
In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, food, and clothes for any weather. I was happy but knew I would miss my own space for the next two weeks. With little room left in the car, we started our “Family Great American Road Trip.” As we left our big home for smaller places to stay for the next five thousand miles, I wondered what we were getting into.
We drove west through Oklahoma. Even though we were close to home, we had many adventures. We stopped for the night in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We learned that cows have the right-of-way on the road!
The next day, we woke up early and continued our trip. We saw deserts turn into mountains. Each day was different, but they all blended together. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly town showed us what we would experience later.
As we climbed to our next stop, we learned that some roads are better for Jeep cars. We saw a mix of old and new everywhere we went. We often got stuck in traffic because of construction. We laughed when we saw the big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. 
On our way to Yellowstone National Park, we saw many wind farms. At Yellowstone, we watched the sun set over bear habitats near the roads. We often had to stop for bears crossing the road, which was funny and exciting. 
As we drove, life at home felt far away. Even the old hotel we stayed in, which had no internet or cell phone service, could not stop our excitement. I saw the most beautiful views I had ever seen. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we started our trip back south. My parents were right. You don’t need to go to a faraway place to find something amazing. 
It was nice to be home together again, and I was happy that I didn’t fight with my brother during our long trip. We took three thousand photos of our adventures, and I knew I would remember the fun surprises we had along the way.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old. She was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job in another country, and her mother, Dahlia, would go with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy was finishing her last year of school and living at the college. She had the best room with a kitchen and a study area. Amy was happy because she also had free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would check on Amy, even if she did not want them to.
Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only remembered a few happy times with her grandmother and did not know her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not very happy, but Daisy was excited to see Rose again. Rose did not understand why her parents did not get along with her grandma. They had not spent summers with Daisy because of this. Rose was only ten years old when she last saw her grandmother, but she remembered it fondly.
Dahlia told Rose that living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and liked to bring people together. Rose expected to get dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon. This made her smile. Daisy was not a typical old lady; she went to many social events.
Before the move, Dahlia and Rose talked. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, exercise, and sleep. But Rose wanted one thing: her independence. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission. She did not want to be told what to do all the time. Daisy understood this.
Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen mobile phone for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They all agreed to trust each other. Daisy would trust Rose to make good choices, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too strict. If either of them made a mistake, they would talk about it.
Rose was not a wild child. She had a few good friends, and her school reports were always good. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This was her fourth school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this would be her last school before finishing. For Rose, it was a new beginning in her life. 
**Questions:**
1. How old is Rose Frost?
2. Why is Rose moving to her grandmother's house?
3. What did Amy get for her room at the college?
4. How did Rose feel about living with her grandmother?
5. What did Dahlia give Rose for emergencies?

Charlotte Grainger says that her primary school teacher first thought she might write a novel. “I believed that writing a book was a big achievement because it seemed very hard. I didn’t know what other teenagers were doing, like going to the Olympics. When I turned 13, I thought, ‘I should try this now.’ The novel I started then is about to be published. I recently told my old teacher about it, and she was surprised. She thought I would write a book when I was 30 or 40. I didn’t understand why I should wait to do something I might be good at.”
It is a winter afternoon in the offices of Charlotte’s publishers. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was surprised to see a teenager sitting there. The book is a big achievement: it has a strong story and is exciting. Nothing about it, except the age of the main character, shows that it was written by a teenager. The public relations person for the book is with us in case Charlotte needs help. But she does not need any support. She is confident, with a bright face and smart ideas, but she is also calm and not too proud.
Charlotte knows she is young. I ask her about the important questions she talks about in her book. “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers,” she laughs. “I don’t think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don’t think I am very wise. I just wanted to explore the idea of taking responsibility.”
She has a theory about teenagers and how they are often shown in books. She believes there are three types of teenagers in stories. “There’s the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows nothing about the world, and the awkward teenager who struggles socially.” Reading about these types annoyed her. “What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who are not lacking in some way. Some writers give the impression that teenagers don’t know who they are because they lack experience. This can hurt their self-belief.”
Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost made her stop writing. “Books by my favorite fantasy writers talk about deep things in life. I asked myself: do I have to write like this to write a good book?” However, she likes a book called How Not to Write a Novel. “It says that if the reader can guess what will happen, the suspense is gone.”
Some people might think that Charlotte’s parents, who are both journalists, helped her get her novel published. Her father knew someone in publishing who read her book first. She knows she is lucky because it is hard to get anyone to read a first novel, no matter the author’s age. “Every writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you are on your own. In the end, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte says.

“Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,” said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. “Now, who wants to go first?” The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He went up the ramp fast and flew into the air, arms waving. Even we could see something was wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, lost both skis, and fell into the snow. “Remember,” Gareth said kindly, “speed can be unpredictable.” 
Maybe freestyle skiing was not for me. On past skiing holidays, I liked to practice turns in the snow. I was not like the teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I was afraid to try because I didn’t know how. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a training center for freestyle skiing in the US. It had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps covered in fake snow. Students jumped and tried new tricks, landing in foam cubes – not a real way to learn for the slopes. 
After practicing indoors, students went outside to try their moves for real. “Progression is inevitable!” the center’s slogan said. “Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best,” said Gareth. “But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.” The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope goes down to the landing zone. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which is better. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, and that hurts. So, speed is important.
At first, it was hard to make my body go fast towards the jump. My legs wanted to slow down, so I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt tired. “You need to control the jump, not let it control you,” said Gareth. 
Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being indoors, but bouncing was fun. Some drills copied moves we would do while ski-jumping, and others helped us learn ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body was doing in the air. Gareth gave us tips. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before jumping, and then I found myself in the foam cubes next to the trampoline. 
We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more mistakes before I finally landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I made myself go fast as I approached the jump, flew into the air, and landed in the right spot. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope, no longer attached to my feet.

'Imagine you are on a rollercoaster in an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you hold tightly to the safety harness. The ride stops suddenly, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly goes up. There is a pause. Then, it drops quickly, and your stomach feels funny. You go fast forward, turn left, and then go upside down. You feel scared and scream. But you chose to come here, just like many other people who pay to enter the theme park. 
Amusement parks are very popular and make a lot of money. To create exciting rides, there are many people working behind the scenes. These include engineers, designers, and marketing experts. Being a rollercoaster designer sounds fun, but it is a big job. They must make sure the ride is exciting but also safe for everyone. 
Many people think rollercoasters are getting more thrilling, but most of the ideas used today were created by a designer named John Miller in the early 1900s. In the past, rollercoasters were very extreme, but now designers must follow certain rules. I talked to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a ‘thrill engineer’, said the skill is in putting all the parts together. Dr. John Roberts explained that it is important to make people feel like they are being thrown around but still safe. 
To create a great ride, the teams must tell a story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, while adding exciting features like tall heights and steep drops. Professor Walker said that in creative jobs, experience and trying things out are very important. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that it helps to love thrills when designing rollercoasters. 
I asked if rollercoaster designers will use new technology like virtual reality. Walker said we should not expect too much from it. He explained that while new technology can make rides more exciting, the real experience of the rollercoaster will always be the most important part.'

At 25, Miranda Ellington has done a lot as a choreographer. She has created dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both things with her busy schedule. She says, “Dancing again reminds me of being in the studio and following the orders of strict choreographers. It can be tense and frustrating. Choreographers can forget what it is like to rehearse all day.”
As a choreographer, Miranda teaches and enjoys working with young students. She says, “A new dancer is often open to new ideas. Working with students can be easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed, but they do not always know their strengths and weaknesses. This means they can accept even tough criticism. Sometimes they challenge what I say, but I like their honest feedback.”
When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. She says, “There may be music I don’t like, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers do not respond well to the music, it can be frustrating, but I must find solutions. I cannot just choose a new piece of music. I wish I could be more experimental and change the music to make rehearsals better. But now, I always work on big productions where the music is already chosen.”
Miranda does not want to stay with one place. She says, “It is important to meet new people. But I must remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I have to change how I work each time I go somewhere new. This helps me not to get stuck in my ways.”
The conversation turns to a recent documentary about ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda says, “There have been beautiful documentaries before that were not true. This one shows real life in a dance company. There is a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections. I smiled because I understood her struggle. She knows she is not doing it right but cannot make her body do what is needed. It is hard to watch, but it is real. People do not see how much work and dedication ballet needs.”
I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. She says, “It is when everything comes together – the music, the costumes, the lights, and the dancers. Perfection is hard to achieve, but aiming high is important. It helps you get away with some mistakes. I have worked on shows where the dance steps are good, but the costumes or props are distracting. That is disappointing.”
Miranda has done many types of work, so I ask if she is a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist. She replies, “People want to label you, but I do not understand why. There is a trend to focus on one area of expertise. I do not follow that, but maybe one day I will be known for one thing. For now, I want to explore more.”

'A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on TV. I said that you can see amazing things on TV, but why stay at home when there is so much to see and do? This conversation gave me the idea for my fun four-day trip and a film to make people turn off their TVs. A friend was giving away his old sofa, and it became the star of my film. I added three wheels and some cables to the sofa and used old seatbelts to hold it on my shoulders. I put my bags on the sofa and slept on it each night, even one night on the beach. Some friends helped me pull the sofa and encouraged me to keep going. I have walked on many trips in recent years, but this was very different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I could stop at cafés to relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of sitting on a rock. I often told people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks me about my weekend, I prefer to tell them how I pulled a sofa 100 miles across southern England instead of talking about the latest TV show. You can see the film on my website.'

'When I read about swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried group trips before. My brother was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be good for me. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a ticket for one person, because the islands are popular with families. I told him I would not be alone for long; I would join ten others to swim around the small islands. He still looked confused, but he smiled and let me on the boat. 
Our group had sent emails to each other before we started, but there was not much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides told us that a support boat would be with us, and they showed us how to communicate with it. We swam a short distance to split us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first long swim of 1.5 km. I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and swum in rivers, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group, not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first swim, and I was very happy when I did it on my own. 
The next days had a routine: jumping in, swimming at a comfortable speed, and stopping to look at the beautiful scenery. As the swims got longer, I swam faster and enjoyed them more. I felt I did not need the support boat much. I can’t wait to come back next year.'

"Being a flight attendant is not easy, but it is a great job. Since I started, I have traveled to many places, like the US and Australia. I work with amazing people, I have a lot of free time, and my job is never boring. This makes it a good job for a young person like me! 
When I was a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family. I flew alone when school started and ended. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to the passengers. Some of them let me help. 
Later, when I wanted to change from my banking job, I remembered this. I looked for a new job and went to an interview. There were many young people there, and many got the job. They were also changing careers like me. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I talked about my skills and my work experience, not just that I loved to travel. Because of this, I got the job!
I think this job is good for many people. There are many reasons to like it, but free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard. There is a saying: 'No one is finished until everyone is finished.' It feels like a big family. Even if we do not see each other all the time, we are still close. 
When I am not working, I do not take work home. If I have difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I will probably never see them again!"

"At the summer camp where I work, I enjoy seeing the children do things they thought they could not do. Most of the children can swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel nervous, but after some encouragement, they try and they all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel great. 
At the start of the week, some children miss home. It is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds who feel this way. We do not let them use their mobile phones all the time. We tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again after dinner, we say it is too late to call now and they can do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and at the end of the week, they thank us because they had a great time.
Sometimes, it is not just the children who feel lonely. Some parents call a lot to ask how their child is doing, which is not needed. Often, their child is busy playing games or doing other things, so we tell the parents to call back later. We also get some children who come dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why."

'Rock the Planet is a musical show where actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after five years in the USA, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! Doing the show with all-British actors was not easy. The UK has more rules about how many performances young actors can do each week. In the USA, they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Luckily, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 
The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night. Everyone wants to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s great that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful Gibson guitar.’ He told me that the young actors are very busy. ‘We have normal school lessons every day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends,’ he said. 
What do his friends think of the show? ‘My whole class came! The theatre has special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I said I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me, and I was happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills and wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! 
The young actors were already musicians, with some playing different instruments, but none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it easy. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is worth seeing.'
